content: Hey @T-lang -- tomorrow's design meeting is on the overall lang team structure. I've prepared a document and meeting plan here. It's not necessarily meant to be consumed in advance, as you'll see in the agenda, my plan is to start by walking over the material. During that time, folks can write down questions, and we'll discuss the most popular in meeting (and follow up on the others afterwards).
@rylev :point_up:
I put a note on how to get in to docs team (just help on PRs, they're desperate for help), but wasn't sure if it was supposed to be a group doc so i left it in a comment
@Lokathor thanks! I think if you want to add any "questions" or notes at the end, that'd be welcome
@T-lang design meeting (on lang team procedures) starting now
I'm getting "The meeting has not started".
I am also getting this
@nikomatsakis ^
I'm having some technical difficulties :)
not sure if that's related
ok seems to work now
in now
@scottmcm are you able to join today?

@simulacrum I added these two sentences to the notes

  • Want to be wary that we don't put too many expectations on the group of people, that can lead to collapse
    * i.e., if we try to create too much structure up front
  • But if we call things a team, there is an expectation that I can get involved -- is that the case here?
    * Is there something to get involved in?
do you think this kind of captures where we left it?

one thing I wanted to ask you is that you said "if we call it a team, there is an expectation I can get involved", but that's not the case, but I want to dig a bit into that:

  • expectation from and by whom?
  • why do we think that's not the case?

Ability for folks to get involved seems like a low bar -- maybe it's a metter of setting and documentation expectations on how one gets involved.

I think that's a reasonable summary -- I think I'd say that the expectation is also that there's a lot of value being assigned to being a team member, and a pull-based team makes it harder to set minimum expectations.
e.g., I think if someone shows up and starts fixing LLVm bugs and posting questions in #t-compiler/wg-llvm, they're getting involved; it may require a fair amount of "self starter" energy though
this reminds me of something @Wesley Wiser was saying that I quite liked, that we should be focused on indicating what structures exist and accommodating the range of organization that exists
It's true that it's harder to set clear-ish expectations, but doesn't seem impossible.
doesn't seem so different from earning your way onto e.g. compiler team or compiler contributors

And when I say value that's both social capital but also monetary - like, it means a lot today to some extent, but I expect it to mean even more in the future to say "I'm a Rust team member" both in terms of what that means to others, but also the level of investment you can expect in yourself

I agree that making sure we have space for a pull-based group is right, and we don't necessarily need the noun to be different - I think the thing for me is I want to be really careful spinning up teams without being pretty clear on their expected working style (which can change over time, that's fine)
e.g., if the borrow checker 'team' wanted to start up and start triaging issues, it may be that we want to say 'no that can't happen without lang team bandwidth'
and that kind of structural insight is key to being able to make the experience work well for everyone, I think
I definitely don't think we should run off and spin up a lot of teams
I would want to phase carefully into the structure over time
Yeah I was a bit worried :)
but I think identifying "area teams" as a possible thing might be worthwhile
I think part of my strong reaction was just that it sounded like an easy outcome of the meeting might be "let's spin up teams all over the place" which was really concerning :)
I think identifying the folks who are key to getting work done in particular areas is indeed very worthwhile.
(and if they're not on a team today - maybe trying to figure out why is helpful too)

If this is primarily a distinction about naming, I do personally feel that documenting areas of expertise doesn't necessarily need to have the terminology of a "team". I do think "team" implies some degree of organizational structure beyond just "the set of people who know things in this area". This is not in any way a disagreement with the proposal of documenting areas of expertise; I think we should absolutely do that. It's 100% a naming bikeshed, related to associations with the word "team".

(e.g. a "list of borrow checker experts" sounds like a group of people we can consult; a "borrow checker team" sounds like a set of people who work on the borrow checker in some sort of coordinated fashion.)

I'm not that concerned about the names, but I do have the general feeling that having too many names isn't that useful, and that we should instead just become better at documenting what each team does and doesn't do
I don't love "list of borrowck experts" though
for one thing, I want it to be documented, and I think it's a good exercise for us to think about path to membership
even if that path is steep and rocky
by documented I mean: I want it to be in the team repo and have aliases and things
I don't think we should expect to have groups like that for every area though

I don't think there's any reason to not have it be in the team repo as e.g. a ping group, which feels like roughly what we'd expect for a borrow checker experts list (just potentially with higher bar to entry).
like, the aliases etc are not what makes a team

I'm going to think a bit about this. It may be something I defer from this RFC in particular and come back to. A ping group would be better than zero, but I'm not convinced that's what we want. I think we might want something more. I actually feel the same way about the ping groups for the compiler; I think we probably want all of them to be teams, and just have that every team has leads, members, and observers, where observers get notified when you write @ping team but are not members -- and anyone can add themselves as an observer. I can imagine us wanting to delegate decisions, etc.
to be honest though I think a better thing than pivoting around the word team would be to discuss how we think these groups could function
and what roles they may have
that should drive the rest

nikomatsakis said:

to be honest though I think a better thing than pivoting around the word team would be to discuss how we think these groups could function

nikomatsakis said:

and what roles they may have

Complete agreement. The responsibilities and expectations should drive the choice of terminology.
And the responsibilities and expectations are the thing we need to sort out.
